{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3753911,"name":"Mete","username":"Undefined","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/u/7feea3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-10-02T15:55:38.123Z","cooked":"

We actually connected every single CANcoder plus the pigeon too. Checked the wires and soldered it correctly and quadruple checked every single one of them. When we start the robot everything seems fine and working correctly. Cancoders giving rapid green pulses and pigeon 2.0 working fine and all. But when we connect a Laptop (Especially opening Phoneix tuning app and starting the Diagnosis) Everything goes to doom. Cancoders start to blink dimmed green light which indicates where cancoder not connected at the robot start but connected after. Phoneix starts to blink red. We tried everything we could possibly CAN but still, none worked.

Hope you can help us!

Try these:

  1. Restart everything (computer, robot, etc.)
  2. Check your power and make sure everything is correct (maybe ask a different team member to look and check)
  3. Isolate and connect each cancoder and pigeon one by one to the RIO (or wherever you are connecting it to)

I’ve seen this issue once before at an event. There was a wiring issue on just one of the two CAN lines (CAN H or CAN L) between the roboRIO and most of the devices. As a result, when the roboRIO wasn’t sending any frames, everything would appear fine; as soon as a robot program or temporary diagnostic server was started and the RIO started sending frames, it brought down the entire bus (since it was driving only one of the two lines).

Double check the wiring for any disconnects on one of the lines or any possible connectivity issue with the roboRIO itself (such as a physically damaged CAN port).

With that said,

Undefined:

Cancoders start to blink dimmed green light

This implies the CANcoders never saw CAN, so if they transitioned from bright to dim, I would also check for power issues / any shorts.

Both H and L wires both communicating with Cancoders and they both have power. We checked for damages on both the solders and the damages and theres none. What can we try else?

did you try only connecting the pigeon to the RIO? (to isolate if it is the pigeon causing the problem or the cancoders)

are the wires fully in (look at the back) and stripped to the right length on all of the wagos (look at the side)?

I don’t quite remember exactly what happened to us but something similar happened in February, and part of the problem was 2 can devices had the same ID. We also ended up redoing CAN, it’s not as bad as you’d expect. We disconnected everything from the loop and slowly added it back with a jumper cable, adding each one back 1 at a time, checking in tuner after each one.
